channel.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
channel.description: I’m hoping to put some tracks on Spotify sometime soon, most likely using Amuse. Anyone have any opinions on whether it’s better to release singles as you finish them, or wait and release an EP/Album? I feel like it probably doesn’t matter, but maybe you can think of something I haven’t thought of.

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?

If you don’t have more than one lined up and don’t create tracks very fast, releasing as singles can both potentially increase each individual track’s popularity and make it seem like you’re more active as opposed to taking a really long time to get 4+ tracks lined up.

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
Ok, let’s get one thing straight. I wasn’t arguing with you.
That may have been how you were coming at it, but it wasn’t how I was coming at it.
It’s possible to have a conversation about differing viewpoints without it being an argument.

(I’m not sure why that seems such an alien concept on this forum, and it gets quite tedious to have that word trotted out as often as it is. The fragility of this place can be quite frustrating.)

But hey… moving on.

I assumed it would be clear that I have no direct experience in the music industry. After all, I was the one asking questions while avoiding making any broad categorical assertions about how the industry does or doesn’t work.

I’m largely going by what I do know about commercial businesses (having worked in marketing for years) - plus what I pick up from friends and acquaintances who are music producers and composers in the music business.
Additionally, I know of examples where ‘released’, yet unsigned, material has later been picked up by a label and given a commercial release.
(Basically, the thing you asserted doesn’t happen, well, I’ve seen that happen.)

As I started by saying, if it was such a hard and fast rule, I was surprised that it was never mentioned in a recent conversation with one such friend in the biz (signed to a label for her tracks, while also working as a professional composer, both for at least 10 years). In contrast to your assertion, she specifically proposed they be (finished up and) sent to her label contacts with a view to getting the tracks signed, all while knowing the tracks were already available on SoundCloud (because that’s where she went to hear them).

I did email her asking specifically about the point you raised and I’ll post here when she gets back to.

Still, you now appear to be saying that only “most” label contacts (that you know) only want unreleased material. Had that been the extent of your statement at the start, rather than implying that no label will be interested in tracks that have already been on SoundCloud, this whole digression could have been avoided.

Even so, I’d still genuinely like to hear your thoughts on my point about labels buying artist back catalogues - and what bearing it has on the topic being discussed.

Sorry if this seems like I’m going off at you. I’m not.
I’m just trying to as clear as possible about where my impressions and understanding comes from - and why I was so sceptical about your assertions.

NickElle:

They might listen to and like your old stuff, but they won’t release it because they want exclusive rights.

…which they would get, presumably. If previous stuff was unsigned, then they could get the exclusive rights for the back catalogue. Seems to me that the Rights wouldn’t be the issue.

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
NickElle:

As far as “flipping” some of your tracks to send to labels, I don’t think that’s wise. Labels want exclusive, unreleased material. They don’t want rereleases because they lose money off of them, for the same reason as I said earlier.

Even if the track(s) in question have only been released on SC and have only attracted a couple of hundred plays? Is that going to bother them enough to say no?

My most played tracks barely nudge 200 plays, so it’s not as if the world’s already heard them.

I had a pro producer/composer friend/acquaintance check out my stuff on SC, primarily for feedback, but she suggested that with a little engineering, mix and mastering (which she offered to help me with), they’d be quality, release-ready tracks and she’d be happy and confident passing them forward to her contacts at labels.

Not saying you’re wrong, just that she never flagged it. I’ll bounce it off her to see what she says.

Now, to be honest, it’s not going to kill me to make everything on SC private. I’m not gonna be upsetting large numbers of listeners, let alone fans.

 
[Edit…

Additional thought…

With labels, wouldn’t it be the case that they’ll take on the unsigned back-catalogue as part of the agreement that they get the future material?

Obviously, this isn’t reflective of the scenario that you’re pimping an unsigned and unreleased track around to the labels, but once you’ve got that relationship up and running?

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
item.dc:creator: NickElle
item.description:
I don’t mean to sound critical, but yes, I do think SC releases are freebies. Not that they’re cheap music. They’re great. They’re just for free and not sold. Again, I’m not knocking this model of doing things. In fact, Bitbird (San Holo’s label) releases most projects for free, even though they’re making money on sales and streams.

Here’s an example of what I mean by planning: Say you’ve got 2 tracks you’re working on. One is a collab track that you are on, and the other is your own original music.
You like the collab, but it’s not really your style, because it’s a combination of your’s and someone else’s, and the solo track is your “baby.” You slave over that track because you want it to be perfect.
So, when both are done, which would you like to have a bigger release?
The collab that doesn’t rep you as much or your "baby?"
I’d release the collab on SC for free and my original for monetization.

As far as “flipping” some of your tracks to send to labels, I don’t think that’s wise. Labels want exclusive, unreleased material. They don’t want rereleases because they lose money off of them, for the same reason as I said earlier.

I agree with the demo thing, though.
I released my music to be sold, but I uploaded little previews to SC and attached the “Buy Link” to it.

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I’d agree, in principle, but…

Most here will have reasonably extensive back catalogues of tracks on SC – and the desire to treat it all more professionally.

If it’s a bad idea to pull tracks off of SC and then ‘release’/monetise them elsewhere, then many here are gonna be kinda stuffed, having to ‘write-off’ their existing body of work as freebies/giveaways and then create a new body of work before they can step up to a more pro approach.

I certainly plan to flip some of mine to commercial release (after a little bit of production fix up and a proper mix and master). Although, I plan to push mine through a label, rather than ‘self-release’.

 
Besides, look at the SoundCloud charts and there’s no shortage of commercial releases - e.g. Post Malone’s Rockstar has 103M SC plays. Full track, not a preview. So…
(Presumably they’re making their commercial $SC via the ad impressions, so it’s not really a giveaway, per se.)

So, perhaps the SC plan should be to join SC Premier, which allows you to monetise track plays, etc…

 
Aside to OP:

It’s worth checking out the options to attach ‘Buy links’ to a SC post (available in the Metadata tab when editing track info).

Consider posting a short (e.g. 30-sec) preview on SC, with a Buy link to the download site/page.

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
item.dc:creator: NickElle
item.description:
I don’t know if it’s wise to release them on SC before selling your projects.
Releasing them for free in SC then putting out for money kinda weakens the punch of your music’s impact.
Doing that is called a “rerelease.” It is helpful when you want to give new life into a track that is SUPER old (like years and years old), but rereleasing a track that is new (even one that is a year old) will make your brand look like a spammer.

I would suggest planning on which singles, EPs, LPs to release for profit beforehand so your projects don’t end up shooting themselves in the foot.

item.title: Spotify: Singles or EP/Albums?
item.dc:creator: akabillposters
item.description:
I’m with @NickElle on this one.
I’d get the good stuff out there as soon as it’s ready.

My own playlists contain many artists who only had a single track released on Spotify when I added them - and yet, that one track has been out there, getting them exposure and finding its way onto playlists - which is where people most likely encounter them.

I’d recommend checking out the LANDR Blog. It has lots of useful and insightful articles about promotion, including how to approach getting your music onto playlists.

https://blog.landr.com/?s=playlist

There’s also the ‘digital’ factor. EPs and albums have become less important in the age of digital streaming. They’re still great for deepening a fanbase, making fans of a track into fans of an artist - or for establishing credentials as a ‘similar artist’ through which many listeners discover artists.
But, it remains the case that music is increasingly discovered by mechanisms set up to promote single tracks.

One thing you can do is check through the releases of your favourite artist who had small beginnings, but who now get good play numbers.

Look for patterns.
Did they start with an EP? (Were there guest remixers that might have helped feed across new listeners)?
Or did they drop a series of singles and then an EP or album?
Was that EP/album new material or mostly a gathering of existing materials?

 
Re: Off-putting upload issues.

I’d suck up any First-World upload problems, rather make your future audience wait.

 
Bottom line, imo, don’t wait. Your starting strategy should be aimed at getting heard. That ain’t happening while you’re holding back on your first releases.
